item.title: Sudan Live Updates: Civilians Feel Strain as Blasts Rock Capital
item.description: Many Khartoum residents were trapped at home without electricity or water as the country’s two top generals battled for a third day to control the East African nation.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Marwan Ali/Associated Press

item.title: Kremlin Critic Convicted of Treason for Condemning Putin’s Invasion
item.description: A court in Moscow sentenced Vladimir Kara-Murza after he gave speeches opposing Russia’s war in Ukraine. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: With Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine, NATO Readies for Combat on Its Borders
item.description: Shocked by Russian atrocities, NATO is becoming the war-fighting alliance it was during the Cold War, committed to defending “every inch” of its territory from Day 1.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Vadim Ghirda/Associated Press
item.media:description: American soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division firing artillery during an exercise at the Mihail Kogalniceanu Air Base, near the Black Sea port of Constanta, Romania, last month.

item.title: In Photos: Families of Guatemalans Killed in Migrant Center Fire Bury Their Dead
item.description: The fire in March left 40 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Daniele Volpe and Elda Cantú
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times

item.title: What We Know About Clashes in Sudan Between Military Factions
item.description: The strategically important country in northeastern Africa has been consumed by turmoil after overthrowing a dictator in 2019, with plans for a civilian-led democracy now in shambles.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Mullany
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Mohamed Nureldin Abdallah/Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rose in Omdurman, Sudan, as fighting broke out on Saturday between two rival military factions in Khartoum, the capital, and around the country.

item.title: Airbus and Air France Acquitted Over 2009 Rio-Paris Crash
item.description: Prosecutors had said they would not seek a conviction in the disaster, but the ruling was still a blow for the families of the 228 victims, who fought for years to bring the two companies to court.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Brazilian Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Divers recovered part of the tail of Air France Flight 447 in the Atlantic Ocean in 2009.

item.title: Ahead of Elections, Turkish Opposition Leader Takes on Erdogan’s Legacy
item.description: Ahead of next month’s elections, Kemal Kilicdaroglu has pledged to undo President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s legacy with a focus on tackling inflation and strengthening democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Erdem Sahin/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Kemal Kilicdaroglu, center, in Istanbul last month. Mr. Kilicdaroglu represents six opposition parties in elections next month against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: In Pakistan, Economic Crisis Mutes Ramadan Celebrations
item.description: Rampant inflation, damaged crops and the war in Ukraine have sent food prices soaring during the Muslim holy month of daytime fasting and nighttime feasting.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: An economic crisis in Pakistan has sent the price of goods soaring, muting celebrations for Ramadan. As Ramadan began last month, inflation was at 35.4 percent — the highest in nearly five decades.

item.title: Killing of Atiq Ahmed in India Renews Alarm About Extrajudicial Violence
item.description: The victim was a former politician, a notorious criminal and a Muslim. Afterward, two government officials described the killing as akin to divine justice.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Prabhat Kumar Verma/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Investigators at the scene where Atiq Ahmed and his brother were killed in Prayagraj, India, on Saturday.

item.title: A Japanese Island Where the Wild Things Are
item.description: In the pantheon of yokai, spooky beings of Japanese folklore embody anxieties ancient and modern. On Shodoshima, an art contest helps bring new ones to life.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: James Whitlow Delano for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Shodoshima, it is easy to imagine mythological creatures skulking just beyond the eye’s reach.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Freeze Sperm as a Way to Defy Russia
item.description: Some Ukrainian soldiers are trying to ensure that even if they die in the war, their partners can still build families. They also want to send Russia a message of defiance.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: An embryologist at the IVMED fertility clinic in Kyiv, Ukraine, which says it is freezing the sperm of about 10 soldiers every week. A bill in Parliament would have the government cover the cost of the procedure.

item.title: Under the Shadow of War, Kyiv Celebrates Orthodox Easter
item.description: Thousands of Christians gathered in the Ukrainian capital to mark Holy Week, one year after Ukraine’s army forced Russian troops back from the area around Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Hoffman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A priest blessing worshipers and their baskets outside an Orthodox Easter service at the Holy Dormition Cathedral in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: What Leaked Pentagon Documents Say About the Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: Some in Ukraine even welcomed the disclosures as confirming what they have been saying for months — that its forces desperately need more weapons and munitions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Erika Solomon and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery team unloading artillery shells. The leaked Pentagon documents warned of looming shortages of the munitions, but Ukrainian officials have been saying that publicly for months.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, WSJ Reporter Detained in Russia, Has First Consular Visit
item.description: Mr. Gershkovich, 31, was arrested by Russian security services in late March and formally charged with espionage, an accusation that his employer and U.S. officials vehemently deny.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Tatyana Makeyeva/Reuters
item.media:description: On Monday, Lynne M. Tracy, the new U.S. ambassador in Moscow, said she had been allowed to see Evan Gershkovich in Moscow’s Lefortovo prison.

item.title: Fox News on Trial
item.description: A lawsuit against Fox News could help decide the boundaries of press freedom.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fox logo in Times Square in Manhattan.

item.title: Peering Into Volcanoes at Tanzania’s Crater Highlands
item.description: Uninterested in the extreme altitudes of Kilimanjaro, a writer opted instead to explore the region’s vast calderas, abundant wildlife and rare forms of lava.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Scott

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Chaotic fighting in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Planet Labs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Khartoum International Airport in Sudan on Sunday.

item.title: Sudan Fighting Escalates Amid Fears of Civil War
item.description: The civilian death toll is climbing and concern over a broader conflict is growing as rival generals vie for control of Africa’s third-largest country.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Planet Labs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Khartoum International Airport in Sudan on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Fighting in Sudan
item.description: Also, an extrajudicial killing on live TV in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People walked along a street as smoke rose above residential buildings in east Khartoum on Sunday.

item.title: How Fighting in Sudan’s Capital Differs from Past Military Conflicts
item.description: Fighting in the country has been far more frequent in the east, west and south instead of its capital, Khartoum.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A policeman in 2011 in Abyei, a dividing line between northern and southern Sudan that was the site of a long-running standoff.

item.title: Finding the Pentagon Leak Suspect
item.description: How The Times identified the suspect at the center of the Pentagon leak before the authorities announced his name.
item.dc:creator: Mark Scheffler
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Jack Teixeira, an Air National Guardsman, in a photo posted on social media.

item.title: E.U. Cries Foul as Poland and Hungary Ban Ukraine Grain Imports
item.description: The European Union lifted tariffs on Ukrainian grain last year. But farmers say they are suffering from a glut of produce in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Enjoli Liston
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poland has struggled with an excess of grain and other Ukrainian produce since last year, when the European Union lifted tariffs on goods from the country after Russia’s invasion.

item.title: What to Know About General Hamdan, Leader of Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces
item.description: A former camel trader who led a militia accused of genocidal violence in Darfur, Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, widely known as Hemeti, leads the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary unit.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Mohamed Nureldin Abdallah/Reuters
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan speaking during a media briefing at the Rapid Support Forces’ headquarters in Khartoum, Sudan, in February.

item.title: Who Is Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan of Sudan?
item.description: Little known before 2019, he rose to power in the aftermath of the military-led coup that ousted Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the longtime leader who was deposed after popular uprisings.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Karim Jaafar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sudan’s army chief, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, in March. Hopes of a peaceful transition to democracy were dashed on Saturday when his strained relations with another general in charge turned violent

item.title: Boy’s Suicide in Poland Spurs Backlash Against State Media Tactics
item.description: A public radio station in the city of Szczecin is under fire for helping to identify a 15-year-old sex abuse victim, the son of a local opposition politician, who later killed himself.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the neighborhood in Szczecin, Poland, where a 15-year-old sex abuse victim who killed himself in March lived.

item.title: Reconsidering Tax Day
item.description: Make it a time of personal inventory, of looking back and taking account.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Death Toll From Russian Strike in Sloviansk, Ukraine, Climbs
item.description: Rescuers were searching through rubble a day after the city of Sloviansk was struck as fighting raged in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters trying to rescue residents trapped in the rubble of a residential building in Sloviansk, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: We Want to Hear From Canada Letter Readers
item.description: An overview of what the newsletter is and isn’t and what we try to achieve each week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The newsroom of The New York Times in Manhattan.

item.title: At Christianity’s Holiest Site, Rival Monks Struggle to Turn Other Cheek
item.description: At the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem, on the site where Jesus is believed to have been crucified and resurrected, a centuries-long real estate spat tends to flare up at Orthodox Easter.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The dome of Deir Al-Sultan Monastery on the roof of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem. Monks from Egypt and Ethiopia contest who owns the monastery.

item.title: ‘The Tale of Genji’ Is More Than 1,000 Years Old. What Explains Its Lasting Appeal?
item.description: The book is often described as the world’s first novel and a touchstone of Japanese literature. But some of its themes, including its take on gender and power, have echoed over centuries.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Why China’s Leader Hasn’t Called the President of Ukraine
item.description: China had been Ukraine’s top trade partner, importing barley, corn and arms. Now, Russia’s war raises the question: Is there still a relationship?
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Thibault Camus/Associated Press
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in Beijing last week.

item.title: How African Restaurant Baobab Fare Found Success in Detroit
item.description: Hamissi Mamba, a refugee from Burundi, knew little of American culture when he arrived eight years ago and learned English watching the “Peppa Pig” cartoon. But he opened his dream restaurant, and the accolades have rolled in.
item.dc:creator: Amy Haimerl
item.media:credit: Ali Lapetina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamissi Mamba, left, and his wife, Nadia Nijimbere, refugees from Burundi, opened their Detroit restaurant, Baobab Fare, in February 2021. They wondered if anyone would come.

item.title: New Mars Map Lets You ‘See the Whole Planet at Once’
item.description: Scientists assembled 3,000 images from an Emirati orbiter to create the prettiest atlas yet of the red planet.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Fighting Rages in Sudan as Rival Military Factions Battle for Control
item.description: One of Africa’s largest countries is spinning out of control, as weeks of mounting tensions between two military leaders erupted in battles in the capital, Khartoum, and in other cities.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Heavy smoke billows above buildings in the vicinity of the Khartoum airport on Saturday.

item.title: Ishay Ribo, Religious Pop Star, Is Winning Over Secular Israel
item.description: The songs of Ishay Ribo, who was raised in a settlement on the West Bank, are a staple of Israeli radio. He is part of a wave of singers from religious backgrounds who are also gaining a wider audience.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ishay Ribo performing at a culture hall in Kibbutz Gan Shmuel, Israel, in January.

item.title: Fumio Kishida, Japan’s Leader, Safely Evacuated After Blast
item.description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida was about to give a campaign speech in the western Japanese city of Wakayama when a loud explosion was heard.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Hikari Hida and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Kyodo, via Reuters
item.media:description: Fumio Kishida arriving to give a speech in Wakayama on Saturday.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Meets Xi in China as They Seek Path to Peace in Ukraine
item.description: Brazil has been reluctant about choosing sides in the war, as its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, seeks to rebuild the country’s ties with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ken Ishii
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil reviewing troops outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Airman Charged in Leak of Classified Documents
item.description: Jack Teixeira, 21, was granted a top-secret security clearance in 2021, which was required for his job, the Justice Department complaint said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering outside the federal courthouse in Boston where Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old Massachusetts Air National Guardsman, was charged Friday with two counts related to the leaking of hundreds of U.S. classified documents.

item.title: Bird Flu Sample from Chilean Man Showed Some Signs of Adaptation to Mammals
item.description: These changes were unlikely to be enough to allow the virus to spread easily among humans, and the health risk to the public remains low, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Adriana Thomasa/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A dead sea lion in Viña del Mar, Chile, where penguins and sea lions have been dying in large numbers from bird flu.

item.title: Russian Attack in Sloviansk, Ukraine, Kills Toddler
item.description: The 2-year-old boy and at least seven other people were killed after a Russian attack in Sloviansk, Ukrainian officials said. His father is believed to still be trapped in the carnage.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Anatolii Stepanov/AFP

item.title: In Ireland, Biden Draws on a Family Story Rooted in Hope
item.description: He may not be a candidate yet, but President Biden delivered a message of optimism to the people of Ireland. It was a possible preview of a campaign to come.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks in County Mayo, Ireland, on Friday night.

item.title: Biden Overcome After Seeing Priest Who Gave Last Rites to Son Beau
item.description: President Biden was in tears after the surprise meeting with the priest, Friar Frank O’Grady, who was given a last-minute security approval to meet with the president.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden touring the basilica at the Knock Shrine in County Mayo, Ireland, on Friday.

item.title: El Chapo’s Sons Face Sweeping New Charges in Fentanyl Indictments
item.description: The charges, in five related cases, offered a panoramic view of how the deadly drug was created, transported and ultimately sold by the Sinaloa cartel on American streets.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: “The Justice Department is attacking every aspect of the cartel’s operations,” Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said at a news conference in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on China to Offer Debt Relief to Poor Countries Facing Default
item.description: There was optimism at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank that China will make concessions over restructuring its loans.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Andy Wong/Associated Press
item.media:description: China has lent more than $500 billion to developing countries through its lending program, making it one of the world’s largest creditors.

item.title: Billy Waugh, 93, ‘Godfather of the Green Berets,’ Is Dead
item.description: He was a Special Forces soldier during the Vietnam War then worked for the C.I.A., tracking Osama bin Laden in Sudan and fighting in Afghanistan after 9/11.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)

item.title: Macron’s Plan to Increase the Retirement Age Clears Key Legal Test
item.description: A constitutional council reviewing President Emmanuel Macron’s law upheld an increase in the retirement age, but struck down some sections. Anger over the plan remains high.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Lewis Joly/Associated Press
item.media:description: A rally outside City Hall in Paris on Friday to protest the pension overhaul. Few expect the Constitutional Council’s decision to put an end to the intense political and social turmoil that the government’s plan kindled.

item.title: How Much Power Should the Courts Have?
item.description: In Israel, the United States and other democracies, bitter battles are being waged over the same question.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon

item.title: The Great Goat War of Southern France
item.description: A former Parisian moved to the country, fell in love with goats and let them roam free and multiply. Her winemaking neighbors are not enchanted.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Corbeaux’s goats in Saint-André-de-Roquelongue. The male goats, whose horns are marked with purple, have recently been castrated.

item.title: Russia’s Ambassador Says U.S. Threatened Retaliation Unless Evan Gershkovich Is Released
item.description: American officials and The Wall Street Journal have vehemently denied the accusation that Evan Gershkovich was engaged in any kind of spying activity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Evan Gershkovich, the detained journalist, outside the World Bank headquarters in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Will Abortion Kill the Filibuster?
item.description: Courts don’t make laws. Congress does.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Capitol.

item.title: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland
item.description: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Decades on From Peace, Northern Ireland Schools Are Still Deeply Divided
item.description: The nation’s school system still sees the country’s pupils starkly divided by their religious backgrounds, years after the Good Friday Agreement brought an end to sectarian strife.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Practicing the Stations of the Cross at the Catholic St Joseph’s Primary School in the Falls Road neighborhood of West Belfast.

item.title: This is how Ukraine has survived the war on its power grid.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian electrical workers inspecting a power line in Kyiv replaced after a Russian strike at the end of last year.

item.title: Learning to Love My Incomprehensible Kiwi Accent
item.description: It’s surprising how hard it is for New Zealanders to make themselves understood in America.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: In New York — and in many other places — New Zealanders are finding it hard to make themselves understood.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: An arrest in the document leak in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Germany Quits Nuclear Power, Ending a Decades-Long Struggle
item.description: The last three plants in Germany are scheduled to shut down by Saturday, while other European countries are looking to expand nuclear energy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Germany’s move to phase out nuclear energy makes it an outlier in much of the industrialized world.

item.title: North Korea Says It Launched a Solid-Fuel ICBM, a First
item.description: If successfully developed, solid-fuel technology would be a significant advance, making the North’s missiles easier to move and harder to target.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: State media on Friday released this photo of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, center, his daughter and an unidentified person, said to be watching the launch of the North’s new missile on Thursday.

item.title: Jack Teixeira: The Airman Who Wanted to Give Gamers a Real Taste of War
item.description: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Michael Schwirtz and Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: WCVB-TV, via Associated Press

item.title: Ex-C.I.A. Psychologist Re-enacts Interrogations for Guantánamo Court
item.description: Lawyers for a Saudi prisoner had the psychologist show some of his practices in an effort to exclude evidence as derived from torture.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawyers for Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri have portrayed him as deeply damaged by physical, psychological and sexual abuse in his nearly four years of C.I.A. detention.
